doc.title: hmmer

description.text: HMMER is an implementation of profile HMM methods for sensitive database searches using multiple sequence alignments as queries.

doc.reference: Eddy, S. R. (1998). Profile hidden Markov models. Bioinformatics, 14:755-763.
Eddy, S. R. (2008). A probabilistic model of local sequence alignment that simplifies statistical significance estimation. PLoS Comput. Biol., 4:e1000069

description.text: Collect profile HMM score distributions on random sequences

xhtml:div.label:
Obtain alignment length statistics (-a)?
Yes No
Collect expected Viterbi alignment length statistics from each simulated sequence. This only works with Viterbi scores (the default; see --vit). Two additional fields are printed in the output table for each model: the mean length of Viterbi alignments, and the standard deviation.
Verbose: print scores (-v) Yes No
Length of random target sequences (-L)
Number of random target sequences (-N)

Alternative alignment styles?
multihit local alignment (fs) unihit local alignment (sw) multihit glocal alignment (ls)
H3 only uses multihit local alignment ( --fs mode), and this is where we believe the statistical fits. Unihit local alignment scores (Smith/Waterman; --sw mode) also obey our statistical conjectures. Glocal alignment statistics (either multihit or unihit) are still not adequately understood nor adequately fitted.
fs: Collect multihit local alignment scores. This is the default. 'fs comes from HMMER2' s historical terminology for multihit local alignment as 'fragment search mode'.
sw: Collect unihit local alignment scores. The H3 J state is disabled. 'sw' comes from HMMER2's historical terminology for unihit local alignment as 'Smith/Waterman search mode'.
ls Collect multihit glocal alignment scores. In glocal (global/local) alignment, the entire model must align, to a subsequence of the target. The H3 local entry/exit transition probabilities are disabled. 'ls' comes from HMMER2's historical terminology for multihit local alignment as 'local search mode'.
s: Collect unihit glocal alignment scores. Both the H3 J state and local entry/exit transition probabilities are disabled. 's' comes from HMMER2's historical terminology for unihit glocal alignment.

Option controlling scoring algorithm?
Score sequences with the Viterbi algorithm (vit) Score sequences with the Forward algorithm (fwd) Score sequences with the Hybrid algorithm (hyd) Score sequences with the MSV algorithm (msv) Use the optimized versions of the above (fast)
vit: Collect Viterbi maximum likelihood alignment scores. This is the default.
fwd: Collect Forward log-odds likelihood scores, summed over alignment ensemble.
hyb: Collect 'Hybrid' scores, as described in papers by Yu and Hwa (for instance, Bioinformatics 18:864, 2002). These involve calculating a Forward matrix and taking the maximum cell value. The number itself is statistically somewhat unmotivated, but the distribution is expected be a well-behaved extreme value distribution (Gumbel).
msv: Collect MSV (multiple ungapped segment Viterbi) scores, using H3's main acceleration heuristic.
fast: For any of the above options, use H3's optimized production implementation (using SIMD vectorization). The default is to use the 'generic' implementation (slow and non-vectorized). The optimized implementations sacrifice a small amount of numerical precision. This can introduce confounding noise into statistical simulations and fits, so when one gets super-concerned about exact details, it's better to be able to factor that source of noise out.

fieldset.legend: Controlling range of fitted tail masses

xhtml:div.label:
Set lower bound tail mass for fwd,island (--tmin)?
Set the lower bound on the tail mass distribution. (The default is 0.02 for the default single tail mass.)

Set upper bound tail mass for fwd,island (--tmax)?
Set the upper bound on the tail mass distribution. (The default is 0.02 for the default single tail mass.)

Set number of tail probs to try (--tpoints)?
Set the number of tail masses to sample, starting from --tmin and ending at --tmax. The default is 1, for the default 0.02 single tail mass.

Use linear not log spacing of tail probs (--tlinear)?
Yes No
Sample a range of tail masses with uniform linear spacing. The default is to use uniform logarithmic spacing.

fieldset.legend: Options controlling h3 parameter estimation methods?

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: H3 uses three short random sequence simulations to estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV scores, Viterbi scores, and Forward scores. These options allow these simulations to be modified.

xhtml:div.label:
Lengt of sequences for MSV Gumbel mu fit (EmL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.

Number of sequences for MSV Gumbel mu fit (EmN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.

Lengt of sequences for Viterbi Gumbel mu fit (EvL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0

Number of sequences for Viterbi Gumbel mu fit (EvN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.

Lengt of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100. Enter a value > 0

Number of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0

Tail mass for Forward exponential tail tau fit (Eft)?
Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04. Enter a value > 0 and < 1

Arrest after start: for debugging MPI under gdb (--stall)?
Yes No
For debugging the MPI master/worker version: pause after start, to enable the developer to attach debuggers to the running master and worker(s) processes. Send SIGCONT signal to release the pause. (Under gdb: (gdb) signal SIGCONT) (Only available if optional MPI support was enabled at compile-time.)

Set random number seed (--seed)?
Set the random number seed. The default is 0, which makes the random number generator use an arbitrary seed, so that different runs of hmmsim will almost certainly generate a different statistical sample. For debugging, it is useful to force reproducible results, by fixing a random number seed.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: These options were used in a small variety of different exploratory experiments.

xhtml:div.label:
Set uniform background frequencies (--bgflat)?
Yes No
Set the background residue distribution to a uniform distribution, both for purposes of the null model used in calculating scores, and for generating the random sequences. The default is to use a standard amino acid background frequency distribution.

Set bg frequencies to model's average composition (--bgcomp)?
Yes No
Set the background residue distribution to the mean composition of the profile. This was used in exploring some of the effects of biased composition.

Turn the H3 length model off (--x-no-lengthmode)?
Yes No
Turn the H3 target sequence length model off. Set the self-transitions for N,C,J and the null model to 350/351 instead; this emulates HMMER2. Not a good idea in general. This was used to demonstrate one of the main H2 vs. H3 differences.

Set nu parameter (expected HSPs) for GMSV (--nu)?
Set the nu parameter for the MSV algorithm -- the expected number of ungapped local alignments per target sequence. The default is 2.0, corresponding to a E->J transition probability of 0.5. This was used to test whether varying nu has significant effect on result (it doesn't seem to, within reason). This option only works if --msv is selected (it only affects MSV), and it will not work with --fast (because the optimized implementations are hardwired to assume nu=2.0).

Set P-value threshold for --ffile (--pthresh)?
Set the filter P-value threshold to use in generating filter power files with --ffile. The default is 0.02 (which would be appropriate for testing MSV scores, since this is the default MSV filter threshold in H3's acceleration pipeline.) Other appropriate choices (matching defaults in the acceleration pipeline) would be 0.001 for Viterbi, and 1e-5 for Forward.
Direct summary output to file, not stdout. (-o)

Output alignment lengths to file (--afile)?
When collecting Viterbi alignment statistics (the -a option), for each sampled sequence, output two fields per line to a file: the length of the optimal alignment, and the Viterbi bit score. Requires that the -a option is also used.

Output E vs. E plots to file in xy format (--efile)?
Output a rank versus. E-value plot in XMGRACE xy format to file. The x-axis is the rank of this sequence, from highest score to lowest; the y-axis is the E-value calculated for this sequence. E-values are calculated using H3's default procedures (i.e. the 'pmu, plambda' parameters in the output table). You expect a rough match between rank and E-value if E-values are accurately estimated.

Output filter fraction: sequences passing P thresh (--ffile)?
Output a 'filter power' file: for each model, a line with three fields: model name, number of sequences passing the P-value threshold, and fraction of sequences passing the P-value threshold. See --pthresh for setting the P-value threshold, which defaults to 0.02 (the default MSV filter threshold in H3). The P-values are as determined by H3's default procedures (the 'pmu,plambda' parameters in the output table). If all is well, you expect to see filter power equal to the predicted P-value setting of the threshold.

Output cumulative survival plots (--pfile)?
Output cumulative survival plots (P(S>x)) to file in XMGRACE xy format. There are three plots: (1) the observed score distribution; (2) the maximum likelihood fitted distribution; (3) a maximum likelihood fit to the location parameter (mu/tau) while assuming lambda=log 2.

Output bitscores as binary double vector to file (--xfile)?
Output the bit scores as a binary array of double-precision floats (8 bytes per score) to file. Programs like Easel's esl-histplot can read such binary files. This is useful when generating extremely large sample sizes.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Collect expected Viterbi alignment length statistics from each simulated sequence. This only works with Viterbi scores (the default; see --vit). Two additional fields are printed in the output table for each model: the mean length of Viterbi alignments, and the standard deviation.

H3 only uses multihit local alignment ( --fs mode), and this is where we believe the statistical fits. Unihit local alignment scores (Smith/Waterman; --sw mode) also obey our statistical conjectures. Glocal alignment statistics (either multihit or unihit) are still not adequately understood nor adequately fitted.
fs: Collect multihit local alignment scores. This is the default. 'fs comes from HMMER2' s historical terminology for multihit local alignment as 'fragment search mode'.
sw: Collect unihit local alignment scores. The H3 J state is disabled. 'sw' comes from HMMER2's historical terminology for unihit local alignment as 'Smith/Waterman search mode'.

ls Collect multihit glocal alignment scores. In glocal (global/local) alignment, the entire model must align, to a subsequence of the target. The H3 local entry/exit transition probabilities are disabled. 'ls' comes from HMMER2's historical terminology for multihit local alignment as 'local search mode'.
s: Collect unihit glocal alignment scores. Both the H3 J state and local entry/exit transition probabilities are disabled. 's' comes from HMMER2's historical terminology for unihit glocal alignment.
vit: Collect Viterbi maximum likelihood alignment scores. This is the default.
fwd: Collect Forward log-odds likelihood scores, summed over alignment ensemble.

hyb: Collect 'Hybrid' scores, as described in papers by Yu and Hwa (for instance, Bioinformatics 18:864, 2002). These involve calculating a Forward matrix and taking the maximum cell value. The number itself is statistically somewhat unmotivated, but the distribution is expected be a well-behaved extreme value distribution (Gumbel).
msv: Collect MSV (multiple ungapped segment Viterbi) scores, using H3's main acceleration heuristic.

fast: For any of the above options, use H3's optimized production implementation (using SIMD vectorization). The default is to use the 'generic' implementation (slow and non-vectorized). The optimized implementations sacrifice a small amount of numerical precision. This can introduce confounding noise into statistical simulations and fits, so when one gets super-concerned about exact details, it's better to be able to factor that source of noise out.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Controlling range of fitted tail masses

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the lower bound on the tail mass distribution. (The default is 0.02 for the default single tail mass.)
Set the upper bound on the tail mass distribution. (The default is 0.02 for the default single tail mass.)
Set the number of tail masses to sample, starting from --tmin and ending at --tmax. The default is 1, for the default 0.02 single tail mass.
Sample a range of tail masses with uniform linear spacing. The default is to use uniform logarithmic spacing.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Options controlling h3 parameter estimation methods

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for MSV E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100. Enter a value > 0
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0
Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04. Enter a value > 0 and < 1

For debugging the MPI master/worker version: pause after start, to enable the developer to attach debuggers to the running master and worker(s) processes. Send SIGCONT signal to release the pause. (Under gdb: (gdb) signal SIGCONT) (Only available if optional MPI support was enabled at compile-time.)

Set the random number seed. The default is 0, which makes the random number generator use an arbitrary seed, so that different runs of hmmsim will almost certainly generate a different statistical sample. For debugging, it is useful to force reproducible results, by fixing a random number seed.

Set the background residue distribution to a uniform distribution, both for purposes of the null model used in calculating scores, and for generating the random sequences. The default is to use a standard amino acid background frequency distribution.
Set the background residue distribution to the mean composition of the profile. This was used in exploring some of the effects of biased composition.

Turn the H3 target sequence length model off. Set the self-transitions for N,C,J and the null model to 350/351 instead; this emulates HMMER2. Not a good idea in general. This was used to demonstrate one of the main H2 vs. H3 differences.

Set the nu parameter for the MSV algorithm -- the expected number of ungapped local alignments per target sequence. The default is 2.0, corresponding to a E->J transition probability of 0.5. This was used to test whether varying nu has significant effect on result (it doesn't seem to, within reason). This option only works if --msv is selected (it only affects MSV), and it will not work with --fast (because the optimized implementations are hardwired to assume nu=2.0).

Set the filter P-value threshold to use in generating filter power files with --ffile. The default is 0.02 (which would be appropriate for testing MSV scores, since this is the default MSV filter threshold in H3's acceleration pipeline.) Other appropriate choices (matching defaults in the acceleration pipeline) would be 0.001 for Viterbi, and 1e-5 for Forward.

When collecting Viterbi alignment statistics (the -a option), for each sampled sequence, output two fields per line to a file: the length of the optimal alignment, and the Viterbi bit score. Requires that the -a option is also used.

Output a rank versus. E-value plot in XMGRACE xy format to file. The x-axis is the rank of this sequence, from highest score to lowest; the y-axis is the E-value calculated for this sequence. E-values are calculated using H3's default procedures (i.e. the 'pmu, plambda' parameters in the output table). You expect a rough match between rank and E-value if E-values are accurately estimated.

Output a 'filter power' file: for each model, a line with three fields: model name, number of sequences passing the P-value threshold, and fraction of sequences passing the P-value threshold. See --pthresh for setting the P-value threshold, which defaults to 0.02 (the default MSV filter threshold in H3). The P-values are as determined by H3's default procedures (the 'pmu,plambda' parameters in the output table). If all is well, you expect to see filter power equal to the predicted P-value setting of the threshold.

Output cumulative survival plots (P(S>x)) to file in XMGRACE xy format. There are three plots: (1) the observed score distribution; (2) the maximum likelihood fitted distribution; (3) a maximum likelihood fit to the location parameter (mu/tau) while assuming lambda=log 2.

Output the bit scores as a binary array of double-precision floats (8 bytes per score) to file. Programs like Easel's esl-histplot can read such binary files. This is useful when generating extremely large sample sizes.

Alternative alignment styles?

parameter.name: altSco
parameter.prompt: Option controlling scoring algorithm

velem.label: Score sequences with the Viterbi algorithm (vit)
Score sequences with the Forward algorithm (fwd)
Score sequences with the Hybrid algorithm (hyd)
Score sequences with the MSV algorithm (msv)
Use the optimized versions of the above (fast)

format.code: ( "" , " " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: vit: Collect Viterbi maximum likelihood alignment scores. This is the default.
fwd: Collect Forward log-odds likelihood scores, summed over alignment ensemble.

hyb: Collect 'Hybrid' scores, as described in papers by Yu and Hwa (for instance, Bioinformatics 18:864, 2002). These involve calculating a Forward matrix and taking the maximum cell value. The number itself is statistically somewhat unmotivated, but the distribution is expected be a well-behaved extreme value distribution (Gumbel).
msv: Collect MSV (multiple ungapped segment Viterbi) scores, using H3's main acceleration heuristic.

fast: For any of the above options, use H3's optimized production implementation (using SIMD vectorization). The default is to use the 'generic' implementation (slow and non-vectorized). The optimized implementations sacrifice a small amount of numerical precision. This can introduce confounding noise into statistical simulations and fits, so when one gets super-concerned about exact details, it's better to be able to factor that source of noise out.

paragraph.name: ECalibration
paragraph.prompt: Options controlling h3 parameter estimation methods

comment.text: H3 uses three short random sequence simulations to estimating the location parameters for the expected score distributions for MSV scores, Viterbi scores, and Forward scores. These options allow these simulations to be modified.

parameter.name: EmL
parameter.prompt: Lengt of sequences for MSV Gumbel mu fit (EmL)

interface.label:
Number of sequences for Viterbi Gumbel mu fit (EvN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter mu for Viterbi E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0.

parameter.name: EfL
parameter.prompt: Lengt of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfL)

format.code: ( "" , " --EfL " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100. Enter a value > 0

interface.label:
Lengt of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfL)?
Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100. Enter a value > 0

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the sequence length in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 100. Enter a value > 0

parameter.name: EfN
parameter.prompt: Number of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfN)

format.code: ( "" , " --EfN " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0

interface.label:
Number of sequences for Forward exp tail tau fit (EfN)?
Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the number of sequences in simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward E-values. Default is 200. Enter a value > 0

parameter.name: Eft
parameter.prompt: Tail mass for Forward exponential tail tau fit (Eft)

format.code: ( "" , " --Eft " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04. Enter a value > 0 and < 1

interface.label:
Tail mass for Forward exponential tail tau fit (Eft)?
Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04. Enter a value > 0 and < 1

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Sets the tail mass fraction to fit in the simulation that estimates the location parameter tau for Forward evalues. Default is 0.04. Enter a value > 0 and < 1

parameter.name: stall
parameter.prompt: Arrest after start: for debugging MPI under gdb (--stall)

comment.text: For debugging the MPI master/worker version: pause after start, to enable the developer to attach debuggers to the running master and worker(s) processes. Send SIGCONT signal to release the pause. (Under gdb: (gdb) signal SIGCONT) (Only available if optional MPI support was enabled at compile-time.)

interface.label:
Arrest after start: for debugging MPI under gdb (--stall)?
Yes No
For debugging the MPI master/worker version: pause after start, to enable the developer to attach debuggers to the running master and worker(s) processes. Send SIGCONT signal to release the pause. (Under gdb: (gdb) signal SIGCONT) (Only available if optional MPI support was enabled at compile-time.)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: For debugging the MPI master/worker version: pause after start, to enable the developer to attach debuggers to the running master and worker(s) processes. Send SIGCONT signal to release the pause. (Under gdb: (gdb) signal SIGCONT) (Only available if optional MPI support was enabled at compile-time.)

parameter.name: seed
parameter.prompt: Set random number seed (--seed)

format.code: ( "" , " --seed " + str(value))[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: Set the random number seed. The default is 0, which makes the random number generator use an arbitrary seed, so that different runs of hmmsim will almost certainly generate a different statistical sample. For debugging, it is useful to force reproducible results, by fixing a random number seed.

interface.label:
Set random number seed (--seed)?
Set the random number seed. The default is 0, which makes the random number generator use an arbitrary seed, so that different runs of hmmsim will almost certainly generate a different statistical sample. For debugging, it is useful to force reproducible results, by fixing a random number seed.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the random number seed. The default is 0, which makes the random number generator use an arbitrary seed, so that different runs of hmmsim will almost certainly generate a different statistical sample. For debugging, it is useful to force reproducible results, by fixing a random number seed.

comment.text: These options were used in a small variety of different exploratory experiments.

parameter.name: bgflat
parameter.prompt: Set uniform background frequencies (--bgflat)

comment.text: Set the background residue distribution to a uniform distribution, both for purposes of the null model used in calculating scores, and for generating the random sequences. The default is to use a standard amino acid background frequency distribution.

interface.label:
Set uniform background frequencies (--bgflat)?
Yes No
Set the background residue distribution to a uniform distribution, both for purposes of the null model used in calculating scores, and for generating the random sequences. The default is to use a standard amino acid background frequency distribution.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the background residue distribution to a uniform distribution, both for purposes of the null model used in calculating scores, and for generating the random sequences. The default is to use a standard amino acid background frequency distribution.

parameter.name: bgcomp
parameter.prompt: Set bg frequencies to model's average composition (--bgcomp)

comment.text: Set the background residue distribution to the mean composition of the profile. This was used in exploring some of the effects of biased composition.

interface.label:
Set bg frequencies to model's average composition (--bgcomp)?
Yes No
Set the background residue distribution to the mean composition of the profile. This was used in exploring some of the effects of biased composition.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the background residue distribution to the mean composition of the profile. This was used in exploring some of the effects of biased composition.

parameter.name: lengthmode
parameter.prompt: Turn the H3 length model off (--x-no-lengthmode)

comment.text: Turn the H3 target sequence length model off. Set the self-transitions for N,C,J and the null model to 350/351 instead; this emulates HMMER2. Not a good idea in general. This was used to demonstrate one of the main H2 vs. H3 differences.

interface.label:
Turn the H3 length model off (--x-no-lengthmode)?
Yes No
Turn the H3 target sequence length model off. Set the self-transitions for N,C,J and the null model to 350/351 instead; this emulates HMMER2. Not a good idea in general. This was used to demonstrate one of the main H2 vs. H3 differences.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Turn the H3 target sequence length model off. Set the self-transitions for N,C,J and the null model to 350/351 instead; this emulates HMMER2. Not a good idea in general. This was used to demonstrate one of the main H2 vs. H3 differences.

parameter.name: nu
parameter.prompt: Set nu parameter (expected HSPs) for GMSV (--nu)

format.code: ( "" , " --nu " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Set the nu parameter for the MSV algorithm -- the expected number of ungapped local alignments per target sequence. The default is 2.0, corresponding to a E->J transition probability of 0.5. This was used to test whether varying nu has significant effect on result (it doesn't seem to, within reason). This option only works if --msv is selected (it only affects MSV), and it will not work with --fast (because the optimized implementations are hardwired to assume nu=2.0).

interface.label:
Set nu parameter (expected HSPs) for GMSV (--nu)?
Set the nu parameter for the MSV algorithm -- the expected number of ungapped local alignments per target sequence. The default is 2.0, corresponding to a E->J transition probability of 0.5. This was used to test whether varying nu has significant effect on result (it doesn't seem to, within reason). This option only works if --msv is selected (it only affects MSV), and it will not work with --fast (because the optimized implementations are hardwired to assume nu=2.0).

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the nu parameter for the MSV algorithm -- the expected number of ungapped local alignments per target sequence. The default is 2.0, corresponding to a E->J transition probability of 0.5. This was used to test whether varying nu has significant effect on result (it doesn't seem to, within reason). This option only works if --msv is selected (it only affects MSV), and it will not work with --fast (because the optimized implementations are hardwired to assume nu=2.0).

parameter.name: pthresh
parameter.prompt: Set P-value threshold for --ffile (--pthresh)

format.code: ( "" , " --pthresh " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

comment.text: Set the filter P-value threshold to use in generating filter power files with --ffile. The default is 0.02 (which would be appropriate for testing MSV scores, since this is the default MSV filter threshold in H3's acceleration pipeline.) Other appropriate choices (matching defaults in the acceleration pipeline) would be 0.001 for Viterbi, and 1e-5 for Forward.

interface.label:
Set P-value threshold for --ffile (--pthresh)?
Set the filter P-value threshold to use in generating filter power files with --ffile. The default is 0.02 (which would be appropriate for testing MSV scores, since this is the default MSV filter threshold in H3's acceleration pipeline.) Other appropriate choices (matching defaults in the acceleration pipeline) would be 0.001 for Viterbi, and 1e-5 for Forward.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Set the filter P-value threshold to use in generating filter power files with --ffile. The default is 0.02 (which would be appropriate for testing MSV scores, since this is the default MSV filter threshold in H3's acceleration pipeline.) Other appropriate choices (matching defaults in the acceleration pipeline) would be 0.001 for Viterbi, and 1e-5 for Forward.

parameter.name: save
parameter.prompt: Direct summary output to file, not stdout. (-o)

interface.label: Direct summary output to file, not stdout. (-o)

parameter.name: save_out
parameter.prompt: Direct summary output to file.

parameter.name: afile
parameter.prompt: Output alignment lengths to file (--afile)

comment.text: When collecting Viterbi alignment statistics (the -a option), for each sampled sequence, output two fields per line to a file: the length of the optimal alignment, and the Viterbi bit score. Requires that the -a option is also used.

interface.label:
Output alignment lengths to file (--afile)?
When collecting Viterbi alignment statistics (the -a option), for each sampled sequence, output two fields per line to a file: the length of the optimal alignment, and the Viterbi bit score. Requires that the -a option is also used.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: When collecting Viterbi alignment statistics (the -a option), for each sampled sequence, output two fields per line to a file: the length of the optimal alignment, and the Viterbi bit score. Requires that the -a option is also used.

parameter.name: afile_out
parameter.prompt: Output alignment lengths

parameter.name: efile
parameter.prompt: Output E vs. E plots to file in xy format (--efile)

comment.text: Output a rank versus. E-value plot in XMGRACE xy format to file. The x-axis is the rank of this sequence, from highest score to lowest; the y-axis is the E-value calculated for this sequence. E-values are calculated using H3's default procedures (i.e. the 'pmu, plambda' parameters in the output table). You expect a rough match between rank and E-value if E-values are accurately estimated.

interface.label:
Output E vs. E plots to file in xy format (--efile)?
Output a rank versus. E-value plot in XMGRACE xy format to file. The x-axis is the rank of this sequence, from highest score to lowest; the y-axis is the E-value calculated for this sequence. E-values are calculated using H3's default procedures (i.e. the 'pmu, plambda' parameters in the output table). You expect a rough match between rank and E-value if E-values are accurately estimated.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Output a rank versus. E-value plot in XMGRACE xy format to file. The x-axis is the rank of this sequence, from highest score to lowest; the y-axis is the E-value calculated for this sequence. E-values are calculated using H3's default procedures (i.e. the 'pmu, plambda' parameters in the output table). You expect a rough match between rank and E-value if E-values are accurately estimated.

parameter.name: efile_out
parameter.prompt: Output E vs. E plots to file in xy format

parameter.name: ffile
parameter.prompt: Output filter fraction: sequences passing P thresh (--ffile)

comment.text: Output a 'filter power' file: for each model, a line with three fields: model name, number of sequences passing the P-value threshold, and fraction of sequences passing the P-value threshold. See --pthresh for setting the P-value threshold, which defaults to 0.02 (the default MSV filter threshold in H3). The P-values are as determined by H3's default procedures (the 'pmu,plambda' parameters in the output table). If all is well, you expect to see filter power equal to the predicted P-value setting of the threshold.

interface.label:
Output filter fraction: sequences passing P thresh (--ffile)?
Output a 'filter power' file: for each model, a line with three fields: model name, number of sequences passing the P-value threshold, and fraction of sequences passing the P-value threshold. See --pthresh for setting the P-value threshold, which defaults to 0.02 (the default MSV filter threshold in H3). The P-values are as determined by H3's default procedures (the 'pmu,plambda' parameters in the output table). If all is well, you expect to see filter power equal to the predicted P-value setting of the threshold.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Output a 'filter power' file: for each model, a line with three fields: model name, number of sequences passing the P-value threshold, and fraction of sequences passing the P-value threshold. See --pthresh for setting the P-value threshold, which defaults to 0.02 (the default MSV filter threshold in H3). The P-values are as determined by H3's default procedures (the 'pmu,plambda' parameters in the output table). If all is well, you expect to see filter power equal to the predicted P-value setting of the threshold.

parameter.name: ffile_out
parameter.prompt: Output filter fraction: sequences passing P thresh

parameter.name: pfile
parameter.prompt: Output cumulative survival plots (--pfile)

comment.text: Output cumulative survival plots (P(S>x)) to file in XMGRACE xy format. There are three plots: (1) the observed score distribution; (2) the maximum likelihood fitted distribution; (3) a maximum likelihood fit to the location parameter (mu/tau) while assuming lambda=log 2.

interface.label:
Output cumulative survival plots (--pfile)?
Output cumulative survival plots (P(S>x)) to file in XMGRACE xy format. There are three plots: (1) the observed score distribution; (2) the maximum likelihood fitted distribution; (3) a maximum likelihood fit to the location parameter (mu/tau) while assuming lambda=log 2.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Output cumulative survival plots (P(S>x)) to file in XMGRACE xy format. There are three plots: (1) the observed score distribution; (2) the maximum likelihood fitted distribution; (3) a maximum likelihood fit to the location parameter (mu/tau) while assuming lambda=log 2.

parameter.name: pfile_out
parameter.prompt: Output cumulative survival plots

parameter.name: xfile
parameter.prompt: Output bitscores as binary double vector to file (--xfile)

comment.text: Output the bit scores as a binary array of double-precision floats (8 bytes per score) to file. Programs like Easel's esl-histplot can read such binary files. This is useful when generating extremely large sample sizes.

interface.label:
Output bitscores as binary double vector to file (--xfile)?
Output the bit scores as a binary array of double-precision floats (8 bytes per score) to file. Programs like Easel's esl-histplot can read such binary files. This is useful when generating extremely large sample sizes.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Output the bit scores as a binary array of double-precision floats (8 bytes per score) to file. Programs like Easel's esl-histplot can read such binary files. This is useful when generating extremely large sample sizes.

parameter.name: xfile_out
parameter.prompt: Output bitscores as binary double vector to file

parameter.name: stdout
parameter.prompt: Standard output

parameter.name: stderr
parameter.prompt: Standard error
